Package projects.spatial.trees

Class KDTree

  • java.lang.Object
    • projects.spatial.trees.KDTree
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    SpatialDictionary, SpatialQuerySolver
    public class KDTree
extends java.lang.Object
implements SpatialDictionary, SpatialQuerySolver

    KDTree implements K-D Trees, where K is a positive integer that defines the dimensionality of the space. By default, k=2.

    A K-D tree supports standard insertion, deletion and search routines, and additionally allows for range and nearest-neighbor queries.

    KD-Trees alternate dimensions with every increasing level. At any given level, a KD-Tree acts as a Binary Search Tree over the relevant dimension. Refer to the course slides and the textbook for exact algorithms, with code samples, of insertion, deletion and range / kNN queries.

    YOU SHOULD ***NOT*** EDIT THIS CLASS! If you do, you risk not passing our tests! The entire functionality will be implemented in KDTreeNode.

    See Also:
    SpatialDictionary, SpatialQuerySolver, KDTreeNode, PRQuadTree

      We define the default dimensionality for a KD-Tree to be 2.
      static double INFTY
      Encoding infinity with a negative number is safer than Double.MAX_VALUE for our purposes, and allows for faster comparisons as well.

    • Field Detail

      • DEFAULT_DIMS

        public static final int DEFAULT_DIMS
        We define the default dimensionality for a KD-Tree to be 2. An application might want to use it, so we provide it as part of the contract.
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • INFTY

        public static final double INFTY
        Encoding infinity with a negative number is safer than Double.MAX_VALUE for our purposes, and allows for faster comparisons as well. An application may use it as given.
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • range

        public java.util.Collection<KDPoint> range​(KDPoint p,
                                           double range)
        Description copied from interface: SpatialQuerySolver
        Performs a range query. Returns all the KDPoints whose distance from p is at most range, INCLUSIVE.
        Specified by:
        range in interface SpatialQuerySolver
        Parameters:
        p - The query KDPoint.
        range - The maximum KDPoint.distance(KDPoint, KDPoint) from p that we allow a KDPoint to have if it should be part of the solution.
        Returns:
        A Collection over all KDPoints which satisfy our query. The Collection will be empty if there are no points which satisfy the query.
        See Also:
        KDPoint, Collection

      • nearestNeighbor

        public KDPoint nearestNeighbor​(KDPoint p)
        Description copied from interface: SpatialQuerySolver
        Performs a nearest neighbor query. Returns the KDPoint which is closest to p, as dictated by distance(KDPoint p).
        Specified by:
        nearestNeighbor in interface SpatialQuerySolver
        Parameters:
        p - The query KDPoint.
        Returns:
        The solution to the nearest neighbor query. This method will return null if there are no points other than p in the tree.
        See Also:
        KDPoint

      • kNearestNeighbors

        public BoundedPriorityQueue<KDPoint> kNearestNeighbors​(int k,
                                                       KDPoint p)
        Description copied from interface: SpatialQuerySolver
        Performs a k-nearest neighbors query on the SpatialTree. Returns the k KDPoints which are nearest to p, as dictated by KDPoint.distance(KDPoint). The KDPoints are sorted in ascending order of distance.
        Specified by:
        kNearestNeighbors in interface SpatialQuerySolver
        Parameters:
        k - A positive integer denoting the amount of neighbors to return.
        p - The query point.
        Returns:
        A BoundedPriorityQueue containing the k-nearest neighbors of p. This queue will be empty if the tree contains only p.
        See Also:
        KDPoint, BoundedPriorityQueue

      • height

        public int height()
        Description copied from interface: SpatialDictionary

        Return the height of the SpatialDictionary. The height is defined similarly to AVL trees, as follows:

        1. The height of a null tree (no nodes) is -1 (minus 1).
        2. The height of a tree that consists of a single nodes (a "stub" tree) is 0 (zero).
        3. The height of a tree that consists of four children is the maximum height of its children plus one.
        Specified by:
        height in interface SpatialDictionary
        Returns:
        the height of the subtree rooted at the current node.

      • isEmpty

        public boolean isEmpty()
        Description copied from interface: SpatialDictionary

        Specified by:
        isEmpty in interface SpatialDictionary
        Returns:
        true iff SpatialDictionary.count() == 0, false otherwise.
